metadata.sermon_start_end: Last weekend I picked up one of those airplane magazines that describe all the wonderful things you can do and places you can see if you buy a lot of airplane tickets. This particular issue had an article about roller coasters. It described the current boom in roller coasters [...] In him alone, in that one man alone, is joy, peace, deliverance, acquittal, and a safe homecoming. In him only. In him alone. That one man. That one name. Jesus Christ. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon focuses on the contrast between Adam and Christ in Romans 5. However, it leans heavily on the general Pauline theme of 'original sin' rather than identifying what is unique to this specific pericope that cannot be found elsewhere. It treats the text as a vehicle for a general doctrine of deliverance.
quotes: In chapter 5 of the Epistle to the Romans, St. Paul... writes of the danger that the whole world is in
Paul assumes that all his readers know the story in Genesis
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify the specific 'surplus' of Romans 5:17—specifically the concept of 'reigning in life'—rather than just the general idea of being saved from sin.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher demonstrates academic depth, referencing Käsemann and the personification of Sin and Death as 'reigning monarchs.' The original context of the Adam-Christ typology is well-handled, though the use of Hebrew/Greek is implicit through the use of specific translations rather than direct linguistic analysis in the pulpit.
quotes: He personifies Sin in his writings, as though it were a reigning monarch
The contagion of Adam’s disobedience has caused the disobedience of the entire race
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Explicitly connect the 'reigning' imagery to the Roman context of power and empire to sharpen the exposition of the 'two kingdoms'.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is highly personal (the daughter's illness) but arguably misses the 'concrete' social or political application Dekker demands. The roller coaster and medical analogies are effective illustrations but function more as psychological parallels than as concrete ethical or societal applications.
quotes: Sophisticated people in the twentieth century long since gave up talking about sin—we talk about obsessive behavior
The airwaves and bookstores are jammed with the appeals of various gurus
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond personal family anecdotes to how this 'reigning in life' manifests in the specific zeitgeist of 1987 New York.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a 'block' structure: a long personal narrative (application/illustration) followed by a block of Pauline theology (exposition). They are not mixed in the movement of the text; the hearer is first a spectator of a family drama and then a student of Paul.
quotes: I have another illustration, quite a different one. Two weeks ago...
In chapter 5 of the Epistle to the Romans, St. Paul... writes...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the medical 'terror' directly into the reading of the verses so the text itself 'expounds' the hearer's experience simultaneously.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: This is a strong point. The sermon moves clearly from the 'misery' (the tumor, the empire of sin) to 'redemption' (the clear CAT scan, Christ's obedience) to 'gratitude' (the tears of relief). It avoids being overly Christocentric by grounding the need in human psychology and suffering.
quotes: It is God’s grace that illuminates the terror of our previous case.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure the 'gratitude' part leads more clearly into 'good works' or a specific way of living, rather than just an emotional state.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon takes the 'lostness' of man seriously. It uses the 'Empire of Evil' and 'terminal' sickness metaphors to emphasize that without Christ, there is no escape. It addresses the 'temporal loss' of living under fraudulent saviors.
quotes: without Christ, you are dead in your sins; you are lost, condemned, without a future
this roller-coaster ride ends in death
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The 'two ways' could be more sharply defined as a choice of 'life design' rather than just a narrow escape from a medical-style 'tumor'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon emphasizes the 'two natures' (Son of God appearing on the human scene) and points the hearer to salvation outside themselves. The 'extra nos' character of grace is central.
quotes: Jesus Christ... has come to our rescue. He has quite literally appeared on the human scene with divine power to save.
Man has no life in himself, it is Christ who is his life.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Avoid the 'fraudulent saviors' comparison becoming a general polemic; keep the focus on how Christ specifically fulfills the 'reigning' promised in the text.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1850 words, the sermon likely clocks in at 18-19 minutes. According to Dekker's Thesis 8, it falls just short of the 20-minute threshold required for 'breadth' and 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the 'application' section to include broader humanities/cultural philosophy to reach the required depth.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a strong theological address that takes the gravity of sin and the necessity of grace seriously, yet it falls short of Dekker's formal requirements regarding length and the interwoven nature of exposition. The start is overly narrative/anecdotal, creating a separation between 'life' and 'text'.
strengths: Rigorous adherence to the three parts (misery, redemption, gratitude) as a psychological and theological framework.
Clear Christocentric focus where Christ is the objective deliverer, not just a moral example.
Effective use of personification (Sin and Death) to convey the 'reigning' power described in Romans.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (< 20 mins) according to the Miskotte/Dekker standard.
The 'application' is too centered on a single family crisis, lacking the 'broad knowledge of humanities' and 'zeitgeist' analysis Dekker expects.
The 'exposition' and 'application' are treated as separate blocks rather than being mixed.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a 'satisfactory' sermon (Score: 6/10). It functions as a form of the Word of God through its focus on the text, but it requires more 'breadth' and a more sophisticated interweaving of the contemporary world with the biblical exegesis to meet Dekker’s ideal.
